</h3>

When we talk about responsive images, we tend to associate it with the HTML way of doing that, using `srcset`, `sizes` or the `<picture>` element. We were able to set different images in CSS using `@media` queries since forever, but the syntax was a bit cumbersome. However, CSS also has a less-known way of setting different images based on the screen resolution: The `image-set()` function.

<h3 id="the-problem">
  The Problem

  <a href="#the-problem" aria-label="Permalink">
    <svg width="23" height="23" viewBox="0 0 23 23" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M13.9326 17.7227C16.0811 15.5742 16.0811 12.0078 13.9326 9.81641C13.374 9.30078 12.7725 8.91406 12.1279 8.61328C11.8701 8.52734 11.5264 8.65625 11.4404 8.95703C11.3975 9.12891 11.3545 9.42969 11.3115 9.60156C11.3115 9.81641 11.4404 10.0312 11.6553 10.1172C12.085 10.2891 12.4717 10.5898 12.8154 10.9336C14.4053 12.4805 14.4053 15.0586 12.8584 16.6055L12.8154 16.6484L9.4209 20.043C7.83105 21.6328 5.2959 21.6328 3.70605 20.043C2.11621 18.4531 2.11621 15.918 3.70605 14.3281C3.70605 14.3281 6.24121 11.793 6.92871 11.1055C7.05762 10.9766 7.10059 10.8047 7.10059 10.6758C7.05762 10.4609 7.05762 10.2461 7.05762 10.0312C7.01465 9.60156 6.49902 9.38672 6.15527 9.6875C6.1123 9.73047 6.06934 9.77344 6.02637 9.81641L2.63184 13.2539C0.44043 15.4023 0.44043 18.9688 2.63184 21.1172C4.78027 23.3086 8.34668 23.3086 10.4951 21.1172L13.9326 17.7227ZM10.0225 13.7266C10.5811 14.2422 11.1826 14.6289 11.8271 14.9297C12.085 15.0156 12.4287 14.8867 12.5146 14.5859C12.5576 14.4141 12.6006 14.1133 12.6436 13.9414C12.6436 13.7266 12.5146 13.5117 12.2998 13.4258C11.8701 13.2539 11.4834 12.9531 11.1396 12.6094C9.5498 11.0625 9.5498 8.48438 11.0967 6.9375L11.1396 6.89453L14.5342 3.5C16.124 1.91016 18.6592 1.91016 20.249 3.5C21.8389 5.08984 21.8389 7.625 20.249 9.21484C20.249 9.21484 17.7139 11.75 17.0264 12.4375C16.8975 12.5664 16.8545 12.7383 16.8545 12.8672C16.8975 13.0391 16.8975 13.3398 16.8975 13.5117C16.9404 13.9414 17.4561 14.1562 17.7998 13.8555C17.8428 13.8125 17.8857 13.7695 17.9287 13.7266L21.3232 10.2891C23.5146 8.14062 23.5146 4.57422 21.3232 2.42578C19.1748 0.234375 15.6084 0.234375 13.46 2.42578L10.0225 5.82031C7.87402 7.96875 7.87402 11.5352 10.0225 13.7266Z" fill="#767676"/></svg>
  </a>
</h3>

As technology evolve, devices are getting more and more complex, and programming languages need to adapt to accommodate for these new functionalities. Retina images  were born to provide a comparable experience for those hiDPI devices, and in web development, we tend to associate them with the `srcset` and `sizes` HTML attributes, or the `<picture>` element.

However, we also had the ability to change images based on the device’s resolution on CSS for a long time, using CSS media queries:

```css
/* For standard devices */
.rick {
  background-image: url(images/rick-roll-400px.gif);
}

/* For hiDPI devices */
@media (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2), (min-resolution: 192dpi) { 
  .rick {
    background-image: url(images/rick-roll-800px.gif);
  }
}
```

However, this syntax is (in my opinion) a bit cumbersome and hard to scale, especially as we’re getting 3x and 4x ppi devices. So how should this be handled? Embrace the `image-set()` function.

<h3 id="the-solution">
  The Solution

  <a href="#the-solution" aria-label="Permalink">
    <svg width="23" height="23" viewBox="0 0 23 23" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M13.9326 17.7227C16.0811 15.5742 16.0811 12.0078 13.9326 9.81641C13.374 9.30078 12.7725 8.91406 12.1279 8.61328C11.8701 8.52734 11.5264 8.65625 11.4404 8.95703C11.3975 9.12891 11.3545 9.42969 11.3115 9.60156C11.3115 9.81641 11.4404 10.0312 11.6553 10.1172C12.085 10.2891 12.4717 10.5898 12.8154 10.9336C14.4053 12.4805 14.4053 15.0586 12.8584 16.6055L12.8154 16.6484L9.4209 20.043C7.83105 21.6328 5.2959 21.6328 3.70605 20.043C2.11621 18.4531 2.11621 15.918 3.70605 14.3281C3.70605 14.3281 6.24121 11.793 6.92871 11.1055C7.05762 10.9766 7.10059 10.8047 7.10059 10.6758C7.05762 10.4609 7.05762 10.2461 7.05762 10.0312C7.01465 9.60156 6.49902 9.38672 6.15527 9.6875C6.1123 9.73047 6.06934 9.77344 6.02637 9.81641L2.63184 13.2539C0.44043 15.4023 0.44043 18.9688 2.63184 21.1172C4.78027 23.3086 8.34668 23.3086 10.4951 21.1172L13.9326 17.7227ZM10.0225 13.7266C10.5811 14.2422 11.1826 14.6289 11.8271 14.9297C12.085 15.0156 12.4287 14.8867 12.5146 14.5859C12.5576 14.4141 12.6006 14.1133 12.6436 13.9414C12.6436 13.7266 12.5146 13.5117 12.2998 13.4258C11.8701 13.2539 11.4834 12.9531 11.1396 12.6094C9.5498 11.0625 9.5498 8.48438 11.0967 6.9375L11.1396 6.89453L14.5342 3.5C16.124 1.91016 18.6592 1.91016 20.249 3.5C21.8389 5.08984 21.8389 7.625 20.249 9.21484C20.249 9.21484 17.7139 11.75 17.0264 12.4375C16.8975 12.5664 16.8545 12.7383 16.8545 12.8672C16.8975 13.0391 16.8975 13.3398 16.8975 13.5117C16.9404 13.9414 17.4561 14.1562 17.7998 13.8555C17.8428 13.8125 17.8857 13.7695 17.9287 13.7266L21.3232 10.2891C23.5146 8.14062 23.5146 4.57422 21.3232 2.42578C19.1748 0.234375 15.6084 0.234375 13.46 2.42578L10.0225 5.82031C7.87402 7.96875 7.87402 11.5352 10.0225 13.7266Z" fill="#767676"/></svg>
  </a>
</h3>

The `image-set()` function allows you to specify multiple sources for the same image, on the same CSS declaration, similar to how `srcset` works:

```css
.rick {
	/* Fallback for older browsers */
  background-image: url(images/rick-roll-400px.gif);
	/* Prefixed version for Webkit browsers */
  background-image:
    -webkit-image-set(
      url(images/rick-roll-400px.gif) 1x,
      url(images/rick-roll-800px.gif) 2x,
    );
  background-image:
    image-set(
      url(images/rick-roll-400px.gif) 1x,
      url(images/rick-roll-800px.gif) 2x,
    );
}
```

With Firefox supporting this functionality in [its upcoming release](https://caniuse.com/css-image-set) (the [feature request for this implementation had been active lately](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1107646)) it’s, in my opinion, safe to use this technique over resolution media queries, with the corresponding `background-image: url(...);` fallback for older browsers.

  </a>
</h4>

That’s it for this post! Hopefully you learned a thing or two about how to progressively enhance the quality of your images based on the user’s device resolution, with this less known technique. Have fun with it!
